moves.1. e4 d5 2. e5 Bf5 3. d4 e6 4. Nf3 a6: All standard stuff. I could have played c5 here, but then the Bb5+, etc, gives me a too known game.
moves.5. Be2 c5 6. c3: Here, an unlikely move is BxN, but nothing clear comes our of this positional sac.
moves.8. Nb3: c4 closes the game too much, and I will have trouble in activating my dsb.
moves.9... Bb4+: Just to get this bishop out, with lots of care.
moves.11. O-O Nge7: More risky: cuts my dsb's way back.
moves.12. Rc1 O-O: Nearly forced, I have to connect the rooks and defend c8. But maybe not: now, white has the simple Nh4, and the lsb's capture is unavoidable.
moves.13. Nc5: Now, the right one was Rf-d8, but I overlooked Nd7. Just plainly.
moves.14... Rxc1 15. Bxc1: Even better was NxQ, since I lose a rook in the process. But this one is designed to trap my dsb.
moves.15... Qc7: With a shadow of hope, if he misses it...
moves.16... Bc2 17. Nxe6 fxe6: The queen is trapped. Now white can potentially go after 3 minor pieces for a queen, but... let's see: a3, BxQ, axB, BxB, bxN, BxR, KxB, QxBc1+! is not a solution. Whew! :-)
